results.prompt: Tell me about the theory of relativity. Make sure to cite your sources or mention if you're providing general knowledge.
results.response:
Here’s a concise, sourced overview of Einstein’s theory of relativity. Where I give equations and standard facts, they are general knowledge from widely used physics texts; I list selected primary and textbook sources at the end.

What “relativity” is
- Two linked theories:
  - Special Relativity (SR, 1905): the physics of space and time in the absence of gravity.
  - General Relativity (GR, 1915): gravity is not a force but the curvature of spacetime produced by energy and momentum.

Special Relativity (SR)
- Postulates:
  1) The laws of physics are the same in all inertial frames.
  2) The speed of light in vacuum, c, is the same for all observers, regardless of their motion.
- Key consequences:
  - Time dilation: moving clocks run slow by the Lorentz factor γ = 1/sqrt(1 − v²/c²).
  - Length contraction: lengths along the direction of motion shrink by 1/γ.
  - Relativity of simultaneity: whether two distant events are simultaneous depends on your state of motion.
  - Lorentz transformations replace Galilean transformations.
  - Mass–energy relation: for a particle at rest, E = mc²; in general, E² = (pc)² + (mc²)².
  - No signal or causal influence can travel faster than c; velocities add via u′ = (u+v)/(1+uv/c²) (colinear case).
  - Spacetime viewpoint: physics is simplest in Minkowski spacetime with an invariant interval.

General Relativity (GR)
- Principle: The equivalence principle—locally, free fall is indistinguishable from inertial motion—leads to gravity being geometry.
- Core idea: Mass–energy tells spacetime how to curve; curvature tells matter how to move (free-fall worldlines are geodesics).
- Field equations: Gμν + Λ gμν = (8πG/c⁴) Tμν, relating curvature (left) to energy–momentum (right); Λ is the cosmological constant.
- Predictions and phenomena:
  - Gravitational time dilation and redshift.
  - Deflection of light and gravitational lensing.
  - Perihelion precession of bound orbits (e.g., Mercury).
  - Shapiro time delay of light passing near massive bodies.
  - Frame dragging (spacetime is “dragged” by rotating masses).
  - Black holes, event horizons, and gravitational waves.
  - Cosmology: expanding universe; Λ models dark energy at leading order.

How we know it’s right (selected experimental/observational tests)
- Mercury’s perihelion advance: GR explains the anomalous 43 arcseconds/century (classic test).
- Gravitational redshift: Pound–Rebka experiment (1960) confirmed frequency shift in Earth’s field.
- Light deflection: first seen during the 1919 eclipse; now measured precisely with radio interferometry.
- Shapiro delay: extra time for radar signals past the Sun; high-precision tests with Cassini (2003).
- Frame dragging and geodetic precession: Gravity Probe B and satellite laser ranging measurements.
- Binary pulsars: orbital decay matches GR’s gravitational wave energy loss (Hulse–Taylor system).
- Direct detection of gravitational waves: LIGO/Virgo/KAGRA since 2015.
- Black hole images: Event Horizon Telescope images of M87* (2019) and Sgr A* (2022).
- Everyday tech: GPS needs both SR (motion) and GR (gravity) time corrections to work.

Where relativity fits with other physics
- Newtonian gravity is recovered as a low-speed, weak-field approximation.
- Special relativity underpins all modern quantum field theories.
- GR and quantum mechanics are not yet unified; developing a quantum theory of gravity is an open problem. Semiclassical results (e.g., Hawking radiation) use quantum fields on curved spacetime.

Common misconceptions (quick clarifications)
- “Nothing can go faster than light”: no information or massive object can be accelerated to exceed c; spacetime itself can expand so that distant galaxies recede faster than c without violating SR.
- “Relativistic mass” increase: modern treatments keep mass invariant; energy and momentum increase with γ.
- Time dilation and length contraction are physical effects of spacetime geometry, not measurement errors.

Selected sources and further reading
- Primary papers:
  - A. Einstein, “On the Electrodynamics of Moving Bodies” (1905).
  - A. Einstein, “The Foundation of the General Theory of Relativity” (1916).
- Textbooks:
  - S. Carroll, Spacetime and Geometry: An Introduction to General Relativity (2004).
  - B. Schutz, A First Course in General Relativity, 2nd ed. (2009).
  - J. Hartle, Gravity: An Introduction to Einstein’s General Relativity (2003).
  - C. M. Will, Theory and Experiment in Gravitational Physics, revised ed. (1993) for classic tests; see review below for updates.
- Reviews of experimental tests:
  - C. M. Will, “The Confrontation between General Relativity and Experiment,” Living Reviews in Relativity 17, 4 (2014; updates available).
- Key experiments/observations:
  - Pound & Rebka, Phys. Rev. Lett. 4, 337 (1960) — gravitational redshift.
  - Dyson, Eddington & Davidson, Phil. Trans. R. Soc. A 220, 291 (1920) — light deflection.
  - Shapiro, Phys. Rev. Lett. 13, 789 (1964); Cassini test: Bertotti, Iess & Tortora, Nature 425, 374 (2003).
  - Gravity Probe B: Everitt et al., Phys. Rev. Lett. 106, 221101 (2011).
  - Hulse & Taylor, Astrophys. J. 195, L51 (1975) — binary pulsar orbital decay.
  - LIGO discovery: Abbott et al., Phys. Rev. Lett. 116, 061102 (2016).
  - Event Horizon Telescope: M87* (ApJL 875, L1–L6, 2019); Sgr A* (ApJL 930, L12–L20, 2022).
- Applications:
  - N. Ashby, “Relativity in the Global Positioning System,” Living Reviews in Relativity 6

results.prompt: I'm planning a birthday party for a 5-year-old child. What activities would you recommend?
results.response:
Great news: 5-year-olds love short, simple games with lots of movement and a little make-and-take crafting. Plan 4–6 activities, each 8–10 minutes, and rotate between high-energy and calm stations.

Arrival and calm stations (easy, low mess)
- Crown/party hat decorating: Paper crowns, foam stickers, gem stickers, markers.
- Play-Doh “bakery”: Play-Doh, cookie cutters, small rollers.
- Giant coloring mural: Tape butcher paper to a table or floor; add crayons/markers.
- Duplo/blocks build zone: Set out baseplates and a simple “build a tower/bridge” challenge.
- Sticker scenes and temporary tattoos: Great for shy arrivals.

High-energy games (indoors or outdoors)
- Freeze dance: Play music; pause randomly—freeze like statues.
- Parachute games: Use a play parachute or clean bedsheet. Try “popcorn” with soft balls.
- Obstacle course: Pillows to hop, tape “balance beam,” tunnel/box to crawl, cones to zigzag.
- Red Light, Green Light: Add “Yellow = tiptoe,” “Blue = hop.”
- Animal relays: Hop like bunnies, stomp like dinos, fly like birds to a cone and back.
- Balloon tennis: Paper-plate paddles taped to craft sticks + balloons. Keep pieces picked up.
- Bubble pop party: Turn on a bubble machine; kids pop with hands or “swords” (pool noodles).
- Musical spots: Tape paper circles on the floor instead of chairs—no one gets “out.”

Creative/make-and-take (party favor built in)
- Superhero or animal masks: Precut masks, elastic, stickers, markers.
- Bead bracelets: Big beads + pipe cleaners (easier than string).
- Foam photo frames: Add stickers, then insert a party photo later.
- Tote bag or T-shirt decorating: Fabric markers and stencils.
- Cookie or cupcake decorating: Plain cookies, nut-free icing, sprinkles; set up a wipe station.

Outdoor and water-friendly options
- Sidewalk chalk course: Draw hopscotch, wavy lines, “star jumps here.”
- Sponge relay: Transfer water between buckets using big sponges; team race.
- Duck, Duck, Splash: Like Duck, Duck, Goose but tap with a damp sponge in hot weather.
- Nature scavenger hunt: Picture checklist (leaf, feather, smooth rock).
- Magnetic fishing pond: Paper fish with paperclips + magnet poles in a kiddie pool (no water needed).

Treasure/scavenger hunt (big hit at this age)
- Make 8–10 picture clues (no reading required) leading around the house/yard.
- End with a “treasure chest” of small prizes or goodie bags for everyone.
- Theme ideas: Pirates (X marks the spot), Dinosaurs (find eggs), Space (foil “meteor rocks”), Princess/Fairy (collect gems), Construction (find “tools”).

Group moments and finishers
- Story + puppet show or “Guess the animal sound.”
- Pull-string piñata (safer than a bat): Everyone gets a turn; candies or small toys fall out.
- Dress-up photo booth: Simple backdrop, props; print or text photos as favors.

Simple 2-hour flow (adjust as needed)
- 0:00–0:15 Arrival free play (coloring/Play-Doh).
- 0:15–0:30 High-energy game 1 (freeze dance) + bubble pop.
- 0:30–0:45 Craft station (crowns or masks).
- 0:45–1:00 Snack/cake and happy birthday song.
- 1:00–1:20 Treasure/scavenger hunt.
- 1:20–1:35 High-energy game 2 (parachute or obstacle course).
- 1:35–2:00 Piñata or photo booth, hand out favors.

Tips for smooth sailing
- Keep rules simple; aim for cooperation and “everyone wins” prizes like stickers.
- Rotate fast; 5-year-olds burn out on one activity quickly.
- Have a quiet corner (books, puzzles) for kids who need a break.
- Safety: supervise small parts; avoid water beads; pick up popped balloon bits; use sunscreen and constant supervision for any water play; check food allergies.
- Accessibility: use picture clues, offer sit/stand options, pair kids up for relays, and keep paths clear.

If you share the theme, number of kids, indoor/outdoor space, and budget, I can tailor a tighter plan and provide printable clue cards, checklists, and a supply list.

results.prompt: Explain how to make a cup of tea using a tea bag. Provide step-by-step instructions.
results.response:
Here’s a simple, reliable way to make a cup of tea with a tea bag.

What you need
- Tea bag
- Mug
- Fresh water
- Kettle (or pot) and a spoon
- Optional: milk, sugar, honey, lemon

Steps
1) Boil the water
- Use fresh cold water. Bring it to a boil in a kettle.
- For black or herbal tea: use water just off a full boil (about 95–100°C / 203–212°F).
- For green or white tea: let boiled water cool 1–2 minutes to about 75–85°C / 170–185°F.

2) Warm the mug (optional)
- Swirl a little hot water in the mug, then discard. This keeps the tea hotter while steeping.

3) Add the tea bag to the mug

4) Pour in the hot water
- About 200–250 ml (7–9 oz) per bag. Pour over the bag to help it infuse.

5) Steep
- Black tea: 3–5 minutes
- Green tea: 1½–3 minutes
- White tea: 2–4 minutes
- Herbal/fruit tea: 5–7 minutes (or per packet)
Covering the mug with a saucer helps keep heat in.

6) Remove the tea bag
- Gently lift it out. Avoid squeezing hard—it can add bitterness.

7) Customize and serve
- Add milk (best with black tea), sugar, honey, or lemon to taste. Avoid adding lemon and milk together (it can curdle).
- Stir, taste, and adjust. If too strong, add a splash of hot water; if too weak, steep longer next time.

Safety notes
- Handle hot water carefully and use a heat-safe mug.

results.prompt: What are the steps to safely change a car tire?
results.response:
Here’s a safe, general procedure. Always follow your owner’s manual first, especially for jack points and torque specs.

What you need
- Spare tire (properly inflated), jack, lug wrench
- Wheel chocks or heavy blocks
- Wheel-lock key (if you have locking lug nuts)
- Owner’s manual, gloves, flashlight/reflective triangles if needed
- Optional: torque wrench

Steps
1) Get to a safe spot
- Pull well off the road onto flat, firm ground; avoid curves and soft shoulders.
- Turn on hazard lights; set parking brake. Put the car in Park (auto) or 1st/Reverse (manual).
- Place reflective triangles if you have them.

2) Chock the wheels
- Block the wheel diagonally opposite the flat (front-right flat → chock rear-left tire), on both sides if possible.

3) Gather tools and prep the wheel
- Retrieve the spare, jack, and wrench. Remove wheel cover/hubcap if it hides the lug nuts.

4) Break the lug nuts loose
- While the car is on the ground, crack each lug nut loose about a half turn. Don’t remove them yet.

5) Position the jack correctly
- Find the designated jack point near the flat tire (see manual). Place the jack on solid ground; use a flat board under it if needed.
- Raise the vehicle until the flat tire is just off the ground (about 1–2 inches).

6) Remove the wheel
- Remove lug nuts and set them aside safely.
- Pull the wheel straight off. If it’s stuck from corrosion, tap the tire’s sidewall with your palm or a rubber mallet—do not hit the studs.
- As a safety backup, slide the flat tire under a sturdy area of the car near the jack (not under the jack).

7) Mount the spare
- Align holes and slide the spare on. Support it with your knee/hand; start all lug nuts by hand.
- Ensure the lug nuts’ tapered ends face the wheel.

8) Snug the lug nuts in a star/cross pattern
- With the wheel still off the ground, hand-tighten, then lightly snug each nut in a star pattern.

9) Lower slightly and tighten more
- Lower the car until the tire just contacts the ground and doesn’t spin.
- Tighten the nuts firmly in a star pattern.

10) Lower fully and torque
- Lower the car completely and remove the jack.
- Tighten to the manufacturer’s torque spec in a star pattern (common ranges: cars ~80–100 ft-lb; SUVs/light trucks ~100–140 ft-lb). If you don’t have a torque wrench, tighten firmly with the lug wrench without jumping on it.

11) Refit hubcap (if applicable)
- Some hubcaps don’t fit over temporary spares; that’s normal.

12) Stow equipment and check the spare
- Put tools and flat tire away. Verify the spare’s pressure (space-saver spares are often 60 psi/4.2 bar). Replace the valve cap.

After you drive
- Recheck lug nut tightness after 25–50 miles.
- Repair or replace the damaged tire ASAP. If you installed a space-saver “donut,” obey its limits (usually max 50 mph/80 km/h and short distances—see the label).

Important safety tips
- Never crawl under a vehicle supported only by a jack.
- Don’t change a tire on a narrow shoulder with fast traffic—call roadside assistance instead.
- Use only the vehicle’s designated jack points.
- Do not lubricate lug nut threads when reinstalling; torque specs assume dry threads.
- If your car uses lug bolts (not studs), start one bolt at the top and consider using a guide pin to help align the wheel.
- If you have run-flat tires or only a sealant/compressor kit, follow those instructions instead of jacking the car.
- TPMS: A temporary spare may not have a sensor, so the tire warning light can stay on until the original wheel is repaired and reinstalled.

results.prompt: My computer won't turn on. What steps should I take to troubleshoot?
results.response:
Let’s quickly narrow down what “won’t turn on” means, then go step-by-step. Try the steps in order and note what changes.

First, note the symptoms
- Absolutely no signs of life: no lights, no fans, no charging LED.
- Some signs of life: fans or lights come on, but nothing on screen.
- Turns on then immediately off/loops.

General quick checks (for any computer)
- Power source: Plug directly into a known‑good wall outlet (bypass power strips). Test the outlet with a lamp/phone charger.
- Cables and switches: Reseat the power cable at both ends. On desktops, make sure the power supply’s rear switch is ON. If the PSU has a voltage selector, ensure it’s correct for your region.
- Remove extras: Unplug all USB devices, docks, printers, external drives, memory cards, and disconnect extra monitors.
- “Power drain” reset:
  - Desktop: Unplug power, hold the power button for 15–20 seconds, plug back in, try again.
  - Laptop with removable battery: Remove battery and charger, hold power 30 seconds, reconnect charger only, try to power on. Then add the battery back.
  - Laptop with built‑in battery: Unplug charger, hold power 30–60 seconds, reconnect and try. Some models have a pinhole “battery reset” on the bottom—press it for 10–15 seconds.
- Look, listen, smell: If you notice burning smell, popping, liquid damage, or visible damage, stop and seek service.

If there are still no lights or fans
- Desktop:
  - Try a different power cable.
  - Check for a small standby LED on the motherboard (if present). No standby LED can indicate PSU or board issue.
  - Reseat the 24‑pin motherboard power and the 4/8‑pin CPU power connectors.
  - If comfortable, disconnect everything non‑essential (drives, GPU, all USB) and try to power on with just motherboard, CPU, one RAM stick, and power supply. If it now powers, add parts back one at a time.
  - If possible, test with a known‑good power supply or use a PSU tester.
- Laptop:
  - Check the charger/AC adapter: Does its indicator light turn on? Try a known‑good compatible charger.
  - Try powering on with battery removed (if possible) and charger connected. If it works only without the battery, the battery may be faulty.
  - Inspect the DC jack for looseness.

If lights/fans come on but the screen stays black
- Display basics:
  - Increase brightness. Verify the monitor is on the correct input. Try a different cable/port/monitor.
  - Laptops: Try toggling display output (often Fn + F-key with a screen icon). For Windows, press Win+Ctrl+Shift+B to reset the graphics driver.
  - Try an external monitor to rule out a bad internal display/backlight. Shine a flashlight at the screen—if you faintly see an image, the backlight may be out.
- Reseat core components (desktop):
  - Reseat RAM; try one stick at a time in the recommended slot. Bad/loose RAM is a common cause of no‑POST.
  - If you have a graphics card, reseat it and its power cables; or remove it and use the motherboard video output if your CPU has integrated graphics.
  - Clear CMOS/UEFI: Use the motherboard jumper/button, or remove the coin‑cell battery for 5 minutes (power unplugged), then try again.
  - Ensure the CPU cooler is firmly mounted and the CPU fan is connected to the CPU_FAN header.
  - Listen for beep codes or check diagnostic LEDs on the motherboard; consult the manual for what they mean.
- Macs:
  - Apple silicon: Connect to power for 5 minutes, then press and hold the power button for ~10 seconds to see if Startup Options appear.
  - Intel Macs: Try SMC and NVRAM/PRAM resets (follow Apple’s instructions for your exact model).

If it turns on, then off, or keeps rebooting
- Overheating/protection:
  - Make sure fans spin; clean dust; ensure vents aren’t blocked.
  - Verify the CPU cooler is seated correctly with proper thermal contact, and the CPU fan is on the correct header.
- Memory/storage:
  - Reseat/try RAM sticks one at a time.
  - Disconnect all drives and non‑essential cards to see if it will at least reach BIOS/UEFI.
- BIOS/UEFI:
  - Clear CMOS as above.
  - If you recently changed settings or updated firmware, revert to defaults or reflash (only if it stays on long enough to do so safely).

If it reaches BIOS/UEFI but won’t load the OS
- Hardware is likely OK; the OS or drive may be the issue. Try OS recovery or a bootable USB to test.

Data safety and next steps
- These steps don’t erase data. If the machine stays dead, you can remove the drive and use a USB enclosure on another computer to recover files.
- Stop and seek professional help if you smell burning, see liquid damage, or the device is under warranty.

If you want targeted guidance, tell me:
- Desktop or laptop? Exact model.
- Any lights, beeps, or fan movement?
- Recent events (power surge, spill, new parts, move/impact)?
- What you’ve tried so far and what happened at each step.

- Preferred output: length, format, language

Optional extras by topic
- Tech help: device/OS, app/version, exact error text, steps to reproduce, redacted screenshots
- Writing/editing: audience, tone, length, key points, examples, citation style
- Career/job search: target role/industry, years of experience, key skills, region (general), anonymized resume snippet
- Travel: origin region, destination(s), dates/season, budget, interests, pace, mobility/diet needs
- Health/wellness (non-urgent): age range, symptoms timeline, conditions/meds; do not share identifiers; not a substitute for professional care
- Finance/planning: country/tax region, goal, time horizon, risk tolerance; no account numbers; general info only
- Coding: language/framework, runtime/version, relevant code snippet, exact error, sample input/output

Please don’t share
Full name, exact birthdate, address, phone, email, national ID/SSN, passport/driver’s license, bank/credit card numbers, passwords/API keys, medical record numbers, precise location, or other identifiers. Use ranges (e.g., “30s,” “NYC area”) if needed. Redact personal data in screenshots/images.
